title: Automated detection of chaotic and oscillatory regimes

author: Daniel Silk, Theoretical Systems Biology Group, Imperial College London

segmentation: So I'm going to tell you about a method of qualitative parameter inference.
So it's not like start with an introduction and the motivation to as to why we be interested in such a tool.

So parameter estimation techniques typically consist of two things, likelihood or cost function, with which we try to measure how well or badly we are able to recreate a set of observations using our model and.
Distribution of parameters.
And Secondly, an optimization routine with which we try to minimize the cost or maximize likelihood.
However, this traditional technique.
Can fail for certain types of data.
I'm where we can often converge to sub optimal hits and an example is given here with the black dots drawn from a lottery resume.
And a trajectory of our model which has been fitted with certain parameters which only captures the mean behavior of the system is a qualitatively unacceptable solution.
And we'll show how our method is able to derive parameters that give rise to.
So the tree behavior or even chaotic behavior in such a way that if we are able to get close enough to the optimal solutions of the system, we guaranteed a qualitatively acceptable.
Behavior.
A second area where we think our method has.
A lot of potential is when we want to use modeling to inform our development of synthetic systems or how we can manipulate existing systems in order to get some desired output.
And here our method would be able to tell us which parameters by how much we should change them such that we're able to get or symmetry stable steady state behavior or even Celtic behavior.

Then, if the maximally athletics bonus is negative, we get a stable steady state behavior.
If we get a maximum of Exponent zero, we get a limit cycle or oscillations.
If we have maximum spend which is positive, we get chaos and if we have more than one positive laptops point, we get high dimensional chaos or hyper kills.
And something that's worth noting at this stage is that it's computationally expensive to infer these from an ODI model.
So now we need an optimization routine and here we turn to filtering probabilistic inference.
So when we wish to model some real life process, often we're only able to measure some of the system states that we'd like to include in the model, and those things that we are able to measure.
We can only do so in a noisy fashion.
And dynamical state space models give us a nice framework with which in which to take take this into account.
So here we have an example where we are able to split the system into those state.
Those components which are hidden and those that are observed.
So left we have some hidden true states of the system.

Subject to some process noise NPT and on the right we have some noisy measurements which we do observe and we take from the system according to the rule given by function G and also parameterized by this UN observed parameter vector theater.
Probabilistic inference allows us to take the information in our observed components and then try and infer those hidden parts system.
I'm looking for parameters, then we try to infer the posterior distribution.
But it's also applicable to state anjul estimation problems where we wish to estimate the States and the parameters of the system.
However, the Bayesian update step.
It's problematic because the terms are correspond to multidimensional integrals, which are intractable in general and only available for linear systems.
In closed form when we do have a linear system then this is known as Kalman filtering.
So we have to look at some alternatives because.
We're interested in money and biological systems.
And in fact, we use our methods.
Needs the use of a highly nonlinear observation function G. So we have some examples here.
And we're going to consider them in turn based upon a key step in their process, which is the propagation of a.
Of the parameter distribution through the nonlinear observation function.
So the extended Kalman filter is the most conceptually straightforward extension of the counter filter.
So nonlinear systems where we simply linearize the system and observation equations.

However, it's been shown that this can lead to non trivial errors in the provocated statistics and then divergents of the filter in the presence of high nonlinearity, and so this isn't unsuitable for our purposes.
Are better approach would be particle filtering where we were able to keep the true system equations.
However then we have to have some large scale sampling which incurs a heavy computational cost and is not able to use with the lapping of estimation procedure.
Finally, somewhere in between we have the Sigma Point Kalman filters.
And in particular, the unscented Kalman filter.
Which is based upon the intuition that probability density functions are often easier to approximate the highly nonlinear systems.
So instead of taking the approach of extended camera filtering, approximating the system equations.
Instead, we try to approximate the distribution of parameters.
And we do this by the Terministic Lee sampling a minimal set of particles which we call Sigma points.

We can then propagate these particles.
These Sigma points individually through the equations.
So true system equations.
And reassemble them in some weighted fashion, such that we capture the meaning covariance of the propagated distribution up to 3rd order in the Taylor expansion.
And the great thing about this is that it's computationally efficient.
